results.title: Mohamed Ali's happy day feast
results.creator_credit: Nicky Tyndale-Biscoe, Catherine Dyson and Little universe
results.brief_description: This poignant short feature follows the story of a young Somali refugee couple who start a new life in Melbourne. It traces their initial ups and downs, and their ultimate triumph in establishing a successful cafe, reuniting their family and becoming an integral part of the local community. Nominated for a Best Documentary prize at the 1999 AFI awards.

results.title: Modulo: variations on a design
results.creator_credit: Pierre Moretti, Francois Seguillon and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: Camera animation of designs for an automobile, shifting between the drawings and the prototype, and suggesting through camera movements something of the speed and vitality of the machine. What emerges is the portrait of a leashed thing, an object that seems to tremble with life like any greyhound. Through the camera and the non-instrumental music the film creates a feeling of exhilaration, of being inside this machine designed for speed. A film without words.

results.title: Modulations
results.creator_credit: Judith Klein, Pierre Moretti and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: A film of playful observation, without commentary, catching in a few simple animated line drawings the image people project of themselves in the way they dress or move. Different types of people - plump dowager, curvaceous dancer, kilted Scot, ancient Egyptian - all make their bid for attention, metamorphosing one from the other in surprising ways. Music by Gordon Fleming, Herbert Spanier, Michel Donato and Eric MacDonald. Camera by Pierre Provost.

results.title: Matewan
results.creator_credit: John Sayles, Maggie Renzi, Peggy Rajski, Red Dog Films and Goldcrest
results.brief_description: A realistic account of the fierce struggle that raged in the coalfields of West Virginia in the 1920’s between coalminers, fighting for trade-union rights, and mine-owners who employed gangster methods to maintain crippling conditions and pay. Features photography by Haskell Wexler.

results.title: Modra
results.brief_description: In Tony Modra’s first senior year, 1992, Modra kicked 22 goals in only 8 games. This statistic was to belie his future goal kicking achievements in an impressive 1993 season which earned him the reputation of Crow spearhead as he went on goal spree after goal spree. Breaking all existing Crow records, Modra started the season in a blaze of glory and marched towards the club’s first 100 goal haul. Along the way he captivated supporters with daring leads, pin point accuracy and impressive aerial displays. 1993 was Tony Modra’s season.

results.title: Material matters
results.creator_credit: Sydney Sharples, R I C H Warren, Ralph May, British Productivity Council and Anvil Films
results.brief_description: Britain’s economy today rests largely upon its manufacturing industries. It is therefore essential that maximum use be made of local and imported raw materials. In Britain, waste causes a loss of hundreds of millions of pounds each year. Coal is the most wasted commodity of all - inefficient boilers, factory equipment and old-fashioned household grates waste as much as half the total coal produced in Britain each year. Within ten years, at this rate, Britain could not maintain enough coal supplies to meet the demand. Factories must keep down to a minimum the number of waste articles, for instance, there is more often than not unnecessary waste from both metal and plastic pressing, spray-painting etc. More economical and time-saving methods are required in the manufacture of parts. The film draws attention to the small innocuous wastes which usually go unnoticed. It is these wastes that add up to a national bill which Britain cannot afford.

results.title: One
results.creator_credit: Robert Just, Mark Tarnawsky and Little Red Filmhouse
results.brief_description: Non-narrated film in which a young boy waiting for his father in an office complex becomes bored. He wanders off around the city and discovers a mime artist performing in the street.

results.title: Once upon Australia. River red
results.creator_credit: Nicholas Hilligoss, Klaus Toft and ABC-TV (Australia)
results.brief_description: ‘Once upon Australia’ examines our dinosaur past, vividly recreating giant goannas and marsupials using animation. This is a world where humans have little or no part. ‘River Red’ profiles the natural environment of one of Australia’s best known trees, the River Red Gum.

results.title: Modern times
results.creator_credit: Graham Chase, Graeme Isaac, Film Australia and Mayfan
results.brief_description: An affectionate portrait of Port Pirie, the South Australian port and smelting town in which filmmaker, Graham Chase, grew up in the ‘50s and ‘60s. This is not merely a sentimental return to the long distant past. Rather, “Modern Times” presents an intimate insight into contemporary survival in an industrial town in decline, a story told with a mixture of empathy, scepticism and humour. Through the eyes of the “mates” who stayed behind in the town Graham Chase left, we receive a vivid picture of a small community facing an uncertain future as it struggles with new industries, the deadly legacy of lead pollution from the smelters and limited employment prospects.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Graham Chase, Graeme Isaac, Film Australia and Mayfan

results.title: Once upon a time, Beirut = Kan ya makan Beirut
results.creator_credit: Jocelyne Saab, Aleph Productions and Balcon Productions
results.brief_description: Two young women, distraught over the destruction of Beirut and curious to get beneath the romantic, mythical stereotypes of the city in its heyday, visit a reclusive and eccentric film collector. In an abandoned theatre they mine his huge archive of films, entering a vast cinematic history of Beirut from the silent era, through the French-directed films of the 1930s, films of the 1960s by Arab filmmakers, to the large scale American studio films of the 1970s. Drawing on hundreds of excerpts, Saab portrays the cinematic fantasies of Beirut that proliferated in the prewar era. From temptresses to spies to villains, Beirut was a playground in which consistently fantastic narratives took place. The two young women literally enter these films. Appearing as characters in scenes they comment on the narratives from a contemporary perspective, attempting to reconcile this imagery with the war-savaged Beirut of today. A historical mapping of the cinematic landscape of Lebanon that reveals an explicit interest in memory, ‘Once Upon a Time, Beirut’ actively seeks to understand how media representations have manipulated the identity of this complex city. In French and Arabic with English subtitles.
